text_en: ‚Äî Son, what do you want to be when you grow up? ‚Äî Self-aware. ‚Äî Oh God, better if you‚Äôd just become an alcoholic‚Ä¶
‚Äî Mom, am I cold or hungry? ‚Äî What? ‚Äî Yaroslav‚Äôs asking‚Ä¶ The caregiver mode just switched on.
‚Äî Hey, what‚Äôs your archetype? ‚Äî I‚Äôm a cat. ‚Äî Why? ‚Äî Don‚Äôt know. Go away.
‚Äî I know all about archetypes! ‚Äî Oh yeah? Who am I then? ‚Äî You‚Äôre Kris. ‚Äî I‚Äôm WHAT?! ‚Äî The one who survived.
Two grannies are watching TV. The host says: ‚ÄúSo-and-so just started a blog on Twitter.‚Äù One granny mishears: ‚Äî What did he say? ‚Äî Says he got fleas in his sweater‚Ä¶ junkie, probably.

Philosophy students are measuring a pole. One climbs up with a tape measure. An engineer walks by, pulls the pole out, lays it on the ground, measures: 5 meters. Students: ‚Äî Great‚Ä¶ He gave us the length, but how the hell do we find out the height now?!
‚Äî Inner voice says: ‚ÄúGet up and work!‚Äù ‚Äî And I tell it: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe in toxic productivity.‚Äù ‚Äî It got offended and left.
‚Äî I was thinking: maybe I‚Äôm not lazy‚Ä¶ ‚Äî Then what are you? ‚Äî Just deeply introverted and protesting against meaningless hustle.
‚Äî Mom, I don‚Äôt know what I want. ‚Äî Then eat something. ‚Äî What if that‚Äôs not it? ‚Äî Then you repeat.
‚Äî Why don‚Äôt you write a book? ‚Äî I already thought it. ‚Äî And the paper‚Äôs gonna print itself?
‚Äî What‚Äôs your archetype? ‚Äî The lunar one. First I shine, then I disappear, then I shine again ‚Äî but never the same way.
‚Äî Better to undersleep than oversleep. If you undersleep ‚Äî you can lie down and catch up. If you oversleep ‚Äî you‚Äôll never sleep it back.
‚Äî My therapist told me to listen to myself. ‚Äî I did‚Ä¶ now I‚Äôm scared. Someone‚Äôs living in there.
‚Äî Yesterday I woke up and thought: ‚ÄúLife is a miracle!‚Äù ‚Äî Today I woke up and thought: ‚ÄúScrew it, what a miracle‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Äî Why are you so quiet? ‚Äî I‚Äôm learning to accept reality. ‚Äî And how‚Äôs that going? ‚Äî Not at all. But I stay quiet in style.
‚Äî Meditation is when you‚Äôre not working, but look like you‚Äôre super busy.
ü§° Inner voice: ‚Äî What if nothing works out for you? ‚Äî Oh, it‚Äôs not ‚Äúwhat if.‚Äù It‚Äôs consistent.
‚Äî Today we‚Äôre working on the inner child. ‚Äî Mine wants pizza again and sulks if you don‚Äôt compliment her.

‚Äî Grandpa, what is honesty?

‚Äî It‚Äôs when you could steal, but don‚Äôt. ‚Äî And did you ever steal? ‚Äî I did. ‚Äî Then you‚Äôre not honest? ‚Äî No, I am ‚Äî because I could have stolen more.

At a lecture, the professor says: ‚Äî The biggest progress is made by the lazy and smart. Because a lazy fool does nothing. A diligent fool makes a mess. A diligent smart one will do it, but slowly. A lazy smart one does it fast ‚Äî and so he never has to do it again.

A man prays: ‚Äî God, make me win the lottery.

A week, a month, a year ‚Äî nothing. Finally thunder from the sky and a voice: ‚Äî At least buy a ticket!

A young doctor asks an old one: ‚Äî How did you become so experienced? ‚Äî By making the right decisions.

‚Äî And how did you learn to make the right decisions? ‚Äî Thanks to experience.

‚Äî And where did you get the experience? ‚Äî From the wrong decisions.

Judge: ‚Äî Why did you steal another car? ‚Äî I wanted to feel justice.

‚Äî What does that mean? ‚Äî Last time mine was stolen and the police did nothing.

A Tiny Entomological Investigation: Why Do Crickets Chirp?

Short answer:

because they‚Äôre horny as hell.

Long answer:

still horny, but let‚Äôs dig deeper, with science, drama, and a pinch of humour.

Who‚Äôs rustling in the bushes at night?

Nope, not a cockchafer. It‚Äôs the cricket, a tiny evening bard with antennae longer than a neighbourhood tough guy‚Äôs moustache who decided that 3 a.m. is the perfect time for a serenade. Doesn‚Äôt matter that you‚Äôre trying to sleep. What matters is that he‚Äôs singing. For love. For instinct. For ‚Äúnotice me, senpai‚Äù.

Where does that sound even come from?

The cricket has no guitar, no mic, no Bluetooth speaker. Just wings. One wing has a little ridged file (think tiny comb), and he rubs it against the other wing. That‚Äôs called **stridulation** (funny word, right?). If humans communicated the same way, we‚Äôd greet each other by scraping a plastic fork across someone‚Äôs shoulder.

So why the concert?

Because male crickets are hopeless romantics. They chirp to:

  • Attract a female. Main mission. It‚Äôs Tinder, but audio-only and no profile pics.
  • Scare off rivals. ‚ÄúThis is my bush! My lawn! My swamp!‚Äù
  • Announce ‚ÄúStill alive, lads!‚Äù ‚Äì the insect version of checking in at the club: ‚ÄúYo, I‚Äôm here!‚Äù
  • And sometimes they‚Äôre just pissed off because they struck out. So they scream into the void like a heartbroken ballad. Meet the cricket-incel, howling into the night: ‚ÄúMaybe someone, anyone, will hear me‚Ä¶‚Äù

Why so damn loud?

Because crickets never got the memo about peace and quiet. Their love songs can hit **100 decibels**, that‚Äôs jackhammer territory. Shame? Never heard of it. Shame is a human invention. The cricket is raw, unfiltered, zero chill.

And your brain screams: ‚ÄúKill it!‚Äù

Yeah, half the planet has reached for a slipper at 3 a.m. thinking, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll teach you to live without love.‚Äù But hold up. The little dude is just trying to find meaning. A cricket has 1‚Äì2 months for romance, marriage, kids, and death. And you‚Äôre mad he won‚Äôt shut up? Give the guy a break!

Fun facts

  • Females don‚Äôt chirp. They just sit back and judge. As it should be.
  • Chirp speed depends on temperature. Warmer = faster grinding. Colder = half-hearted effort.
  • There‚Äôs even a formula to calculate air temperature from chirps per second. The cricket, your pocket weather station.

Conclusion

The cricket is an evening crooner in love with the world. He breaks nothing, demands no salary, doesn‚Äôt whine in the comments. He just sings. We either listen or slam the window shut.

P.S. Next time you hear that chirping, remember: someone out there just really, really wants love. And has wings. And killer antennae. And a natural talent for percussion. üéª

A Tiny Gastropod Study: Why Are Snails So Damn Slow?

Short answer:

Because they‚Äôve got nowhere to be.

Long answer:

Still nowhere, but let‚Äôs break it down anyway.

Who is the snail, really?

The ultimate introvert of the animal kingdom: carries his house on his back, is always home, and never says ‚Äúshit, forgot my keys‚Äù. A minimalist, a Zen guru, and a slow-motion master, all rolled into one slimy package.

Why the glacial pace?

  1. Physics. A snail‚Äôs muscles feel exactly like yours at 6 a.m. when the alarm goes off. Technically possible to move, but with maximum grumbling.
  2. Strategy. Why sprint when the lettuce isn‚Äôt running away?
  3. Philosophy. The snail looks at the world and says: ‚ÄúYou guys go ahead and rush, I‚Äôll just enjoy this dewdrop.‚Äù

What‚Äôs with all that slime?

It‚Äôs their Wi-Fi: invisible, but life stops without it. Slime = life lubricant. Keeps the belly from shredding on asphalt. Bonus: nobody wants to eat something that slimy. Even frogs think twice.

Do snails even have romance?

Hell yes. Just extremely slow and slightly weird.

  • They find each other by following slime trails (think scented love letters).
  • Then begins the longest date in history: slow circling, tentacle hugs, gentle touching‚Ä¶ a full snail waltz.
  • This can last several hours. In snail time, that‚Äôs a Hollywood romance.
  • And then, surprise! The **‚Äúlove dart‚Äù**. One snail stabs the other with a tiny calcium arrow. Not to kill, but to spike fertility. Basically nature‚Äôs Red Bull for sperm.
  • After that, DNA swap happens and both can lay eggs.

So it‚Äôs not ‚Äúbumped into each other, done‚Äù. It‚Äôs a proper courtship ritual, just in ultra-slow-motion.

Fun facts

  • Snails can sleep up to **3 years** straight. World champions of excuses: ‚ÄúSorry, overslept.‚Äù
  • They have more teeth than a shark. But instead of ‚Äúrawr‚Äù they politely nibble salad.
  • They are **hermaphrodites**. Every snail is both dude and chick. Whoever you are, you‚Äôre compatible.
  • Their ‚Äúlove duel‚Äù can outlast a human family argument.

Conclusion

The snail has proven: you don‚Äôt need to run to survive. You can crawl, leave a slime trail, and still have a home, food, and mind-blowing (slow) sex. Plus hours-long romance and your very own Cupid‚Äôs arrow.

P.S. Next time you see a snail, don‚Äôt go ‚Äúew, slimy‚Äù. Remember: that‚Äôs a tiny Zen master, a slow-motion lover, and a walking weather station on four stubby legs. üêå

Mini Feline Investigation: Why Do Cats Act Like Gods?

Introduction

When a dog sees its owner feeding it, it thinks: ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a god because he takes care of me.‚Äù When a cat sees its owner feeding it, it thinks: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a god because he takes care of me.‚Äù That, right there, is the whole difference.

Why do cats purr?

  • Pure bliss. Petting, food, warmth: perfect.
  • Stress relief. Purring calms them down too.
  • Manipulation 101. Purrs on your lap ‚Üí you‚Äôre not moving, even if your legs are dead.

Basically, purring is the universal ‚ÄúSummon love & food‚Äù button.

Why do cats act like they own the place?

Because they genuinely believe they do.

  • You bought a couch? That‚Äôs his couch now.
  • You brought a box? His box.
  • You want to sleep? He‚Äôll decide if you‚Äôre allowed.

The cat looks at you and thinks: ‚ÄúMy two-legged servant did well today. I‚Äôll reward him with a tail pat.‚Äù

Cat philosophy 101

Master of subtle domination. Tactics:

  1. Let the human think they‚Äôre in charge.
  2. Park ass on the laptop at the worst possible moment.
  3. Knock a glass off the table to remind everyone who actually runs this show.

All with the most innocent eyes on the planet.

Fun facts

  • Cats sleep an average of **16 hours** a day. The rest of the time they eat, groom, and plot the next assault on your houseplant.
  • Science has proven they recognize their name. They just pretend they don‚Äôt.
  • They see in the dark better than us, yet still crash into furniture. Probably for the lulz.

Conclusion

A cat is a tiny furry deity who conquered your apartment without firing a single shot. Pays no rent, uses everything. Does no work, gets fed anyway. Never speaks, yet always gets his way.

And we still worship the little bastard. Because a house without a cat is empty, and a house with a cat is an absurd theatre where the lead actor always wins.

P.S. Next time your kitty sits on your keyboard, remember: she‚Äôs just **updating her servant‚Äôs firmware** üêæ.

Why Do Cats Love Boxes So Damn Much? Cardboard Philosophy of Furry Strategists

Introduction

We think a box is just a toy for a cat. Wrong. It‚Äôs a personal fortress, an observation post, a power spot, and a mirror of the feline soul all at once. If there‚Äôs a cat in the house, there will be a box. Even if you buy a ‚Ç¨200 cat bed, the little emperor will still choose the cardboard it came in.

1. Safety instinct ‚Äì legacy of predator and prey

A cat is both hunter and potential lunch. That‚Äôs why it needs to see everything while staying invisible. A box = hideout with panoramic view: cosy, quiet, dark, zero risk. A 2014 Utrecht University study showed shelter cats given boxes adapted twice as fast and had dramatically lower stress in days. The box is a psychological bunker: chaos outside, peace inside.

2. The ambush position

Cats aren‚Äôt just hunters; they‚Äôre ambush masters. In the wild they stalk from cover. At home the cover is a box. Every bag, box, or upside-down saucepan becomes a ‚Äúsniper nest‚Äù. He sits, stares, and thinks: ‚ÄúHuman foot incoming‚Ä¶ three seconds till paw attack.‚Äù Inside the box he feels like a four-star general who actually controls something.

3. Sensory therapy: feline Zen

Cardboard isn‚Äôt just material; it‚Äôs warm, smells like wood, rustles softly, flexes a bit, absorbs sound. Perfect chill zone. Some researchers say the tight space gives a ‚Äúbody hug‚Äù effect: cortisol drops, breathing evens out, cat reboots. Humans pay for yoga and meditation retreats. Cats just climb into a shoebox and reach nirvana.

4. Bags ‚Äì extreme mode for pros

A plastic bag is a box with added danger. It rustles, moves, smells mysterious. Instant quest: exploration + play + instinct check. Every step makes noise ‚Äì instant feedback: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm alive, this is my turf!‚Äù Sometimes the bag fights back too loud ‚Üí cat explodes out like it‚Äôs a grenade, then casually strolls back in thirty seconds later to investigate again.

5. Box as psychological metaphor

The world is huge, loud, unpredictable. A box is small, stable, mine. When a cat sits in a box, he‚Äôs not hiding; he‚Äôs structuring chaos, drawing borders he can rule. It‚Äôs cat-style meditation.

6. Science & philosophy angle

Ethologists: cats think spatially ‚Äì control the space, control yourself. Psychologists: humans do the exact same thing with ‚Äúsafe zones‚Äù. So the box is the feline version of personal space.

Conclusion

A box is not just a box. It‚Äôs the entire cat philosophy of existence. Instinct, psychology, and pure comfort converge there. Inside, the cat is his own universe, king, patient, and therapist rolled into one furry ball. So next time your cat squeezes into a box, don‚Äôt laugh. He‚Äôs probably running a self-regulation session, lowering anxiety, and perfecting his path to inner Zen.
